seg.seg: ... we carry high. 1. Indra says: I will go close to him [and] I will do such effort, that he again, as before,
I will go to him and I will make effort so that again … [his] former …
(will be in possession of his tusks. The god) says: this was precisely our wish. Thereupon Indra disappeared into the air space, [and,] (appearing) before the Bodhisattva,

(he says:) Oh lord of elephants, indeed a thing extremely hard to do you have done. Has there been, by any chance, satisfaction for you (in) this (pain of ripping out) your veins, sinews, [your] flesh [and your] tusks?
The Bodhisattva says: By no means has there been [satisfaction] for me, for, because I remember the pains of the hell inhabitants,
(it was my) wish (to do others good). For without doing good to others, there is no Buddha-hood. How then should I have gained satisfaction from [my] own pain? Indra
How could I have had satisfaction from my own sorrow?
(says:) ... Unbelievable is this matter. Therefore you shall let us see one believable matter. The elephant says: See, oh king of gods!
... (If I,) in truth, by ripping out my sinews, veins [and] teeth, through the pain that surpasses the pain of the hell inhabitants, [my] spirit
Nor does life in the forest seem to me such a hardship, my lord.
[and] my heart have not satisfied), or if I (through precisely this) truth should certainly achieve the dignity of Buddha, [then] the six tusks should appear for me at once in full, just like before.
(Him having said this), immediately the six tusks, like a triple crescent of the moon, were visible to him in one row. When they saw this, on earth
Als sie das sahen, erhob sich auf der Erde [und] (im Luftraum bei Göttern [und] Menschen) große Freude.
When they saw this, great joy arose on earth [and] in the airspace among gods [and] humans.
(and in the air space among humans and gods) great joy rose up. Thereupon Indra, having recognized the good creature as one certainly to arise as a Buddha, says
... to the Bodhisattva: Oh [you], who have every good quality, I see (you) as one adorned and decorated with the 32 marks, [as one] (certainly achieving) the dignity of Buddha.
When you have achieved the dignity of Buddha, may you remember me as well. Having spoken thus, Indra disappeared right there.
Wenn du die Buddhawürde erlangt hast, mögest du dich auch meiner erinnern.
When you have attained the Buddha-rank, may you remember me as well.
